settings.instructions:
Overview

This is the INL1Quiz for the Non-Cryptographic Attacks lecture. You must get 100% to pass the course. You can retake it. I recommend that you attempt it before the corresponding lecture and then retake it again afterwards.

Grading

If you fail, you will have to go study a bit more and complement your answers. There is a one hour cool-down between attempts. You must have 100% correct answers to pass. Questions will not give partial credit, you get either full score or none.

I suggest that you write down a short motivation for each answer, such that you can review them for the next attempt.

There is no deadline. (Well, the deadline is when you want to get the grade. When all INL1 assignments have a passing grade in Canvas, they'll be automatically transferred to LADOK. This is done once a week, then there might be a few days delay since one of us will have to see the email notification and go certify the results---i.e. click OK---manually in LADOK.)

entry.title: Side-channel attacks
entry.item_body: Select all statements that are true about side-channel attacks.

choices.item_body: Side-channel attacks exploit information leakage through physical implementation characteristics such as timing, power consumption, or electromagnetic emissions.
Side-channel attacks are due to physical implementation flaws, not theoretical weaknesses in the cryptographic algorithm.
Side-channel attacks exploit unintended channels in the implementation that were not considered in the algorithm's security analysis.
Side-channel attacks can work even when the cryptographic algorithm is mathematically secure and properly implemented.
Social engineering is a type of side-channel attack since it exploits human weaknesses rather than algorithmic ones.
Brute force attacks are considered side-channel attacks because they exploit weaknesses in key generation.
Cryptanalytic attacks that exploit mathematical structure are a form of side-channel attack.
Side-channel attacks require breaking the underlying mathematical problem (e.g., factoring large numbers for RSA).

entry.title: Active vs passive side-channels
entry.item_body: Select all statements that correctly classify side-channel attacks as active or passive.

choices.item_body: Passive attack: Recording electromagnetic emissions from a device to reconstruct information displayed on a screen.
Passive attack: Monitoring power consumption patterns during encryption operations to infer key information.
Passive attack: Measuring timing variations in cryptographic operations without interacting with the target.
Active attack: Forcing a device to encrypt chosen plaintexts while measuring its power consumption.
Active attack: Injecting faults during computation by techniques such as Rowhammer.
Social engineering is a type of passive side-channel attack since it only involves observation.
All side-channel attacks require physical access to the target device.
Active side-channel attacks must break the encryption algorithm to be successful.

entry.title: Efficient implementation and side-channels
entry.item_body: Select all statements that are true about efficient implementation of cryptographic operations and their relationship to side-channel attacks.

choices.item_body: Binary exponentiation (square-and-multiply) performs different operations depending on whether exponent bits are 0 or 1, which can leak information through timing.
Timing attacks on RSA can exploit the fact that multiplication and squaring operations may take different amounts of time.
Constant-time implementations perform the same sequence of operations regardless of secret data values to prevent timing leakage.
k-ary and window methods for exponentiation process multiple bits at once, which can introduce timing variations that leak information about the exponent.
There is often a trade-off between performance optimization and side-channel resistance: faster algorithms may introduce more timing variation.
All exponentiation algorithms execute in constant time regardless of the exponent value.
Using larger window sizes (larger k values) in k-ary exponentiation always improves both performance and security.
Montgomery multiplication completely eliminates all timing side-channels in modular exponentiation.
The choice of exponentiation algorithm has no security implications as long as the mathematical operations are correct.

entry.title: AES cache timing attacks
entry.item_body: Select all statements that are true about cache timing attacks on AES.

choices.item_body: AES implementations that use table lookups (S-box lookups) create data-dependent memory access patterns.
Cache hits are faster than cache misses, creating measurable timing variations that can leak information.
The memory access patterns during S-box lookups can correlate with secret key material.
An attacker can measure timing differences across many encryption operations to statistically infer key bits.
Cache timing attacks work even when the AES algorithm itself is mathematically secure.
Cache timing attacks exploit mathematical weaknesses in the AES S-box design.
Cache timing attacks only work if the attacker has physical access to the hardware running AES.
Using longer key sizes (256-bit instead of 128-bit) completely prevents cache timing attacks on AES.
Modern processors are immune to cache timing attacks due to hardware countermeasures.

entry.title: Modern attack techniques
entry.item_body: Select all statements that correctly describe Spectre, Rowhammer, and TOCTTOU attacks.

choices.item_body: Spectre exploits speculative execution in modern CPUs to access unauthorized memory.
Spectre uses cache side-channels to leak information from speculatively executed instructions.
Rowhammer is a fault injection attack that uses repeated memory row access to induce bit flips.
Rowhammer can cause bit flips in adjacent memory rows due to electrical interference.
TOCTTOU (Time-Of-Check Time-Of-Use) is a race condition vulnerability where the state changes between a security check and the use of a resource.
Spectre attacks break the mathematical security of encryption algorithms.
Rowhammer attacks only affect old DDR2 memory and have been completely eliminated in modern DDR4 and DDR5 memory.
TOCTTOU is a type of side-channel attack that measures timing variations.
Software patches and microcode updates can completely eliminate all Spectre, Rowhammer, and TOCTTOU vulnerabilities.

entry.title: Countermeasures
entry.item_body: Select all statements that are true about countermeasures against side-channel attacks.

choices.item_body: Constant-time implementations avoid data-dependent timing variations by ensuring all execution paths take the same time.
Masking and blinding techniques randomize intermediate values during computation to reduce information leakage.
Cache-oblivious algorithms are designed to minimize timing variations caused by cache behavior.
AES-NI hardware instructions provide resistance to cache timing attacks by performing operations without table lookups.
Physical shielding such as Faraday cages can reduce electromagnetic emissions that could be exploited.
Algorithmic countermeasures such as exponent blinding in RSA can defend against timing attacks on private key operations.
Using longer cryptographic keys (e.g., 256-bit instead of 128-bit) eliminates all side-channel vulnerabilities.
Asymmetric cryptography (RSA, ECC) is inherently immune to all side-channel attacks.
Software updates alone can eliminate all hardware-based side-channel vulnerabilities.
Side-channel attacks only affect legacy cryptographic systems; modern implementations are immune.
